content.p: The number of sales that a telemarketing salesperson makes in an hour is a random variable X having the following probability distribution:

body.p: Which of the following tables represents the probability distribution of X?

response.feedback: Incorrect. While it is true that the possible values that X can take are 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4, the corresponding probabilities are incorrect. In order to find the probability that X takes a certain value, you need to plug that value into the formula. So, for example, P(X = 1) = (1 + 2)(5 - 1) / 50 = 12/50. Please try again.

Incorrect. While it is true that the possible values that X can take are 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4, the corresponding probabilities are incorrect. Note also that your selection is not a legitimate probability distribution, since the sum of the probabilities of all possible values is not 1, as it should be. In order to find the probability that X takes a certain value, you need to plug that value into the formula. So, for example, P(X = 1) = (1 + 2)(5 - 1) / 50 = 12/50. Please try again.

Incorrect. Note that X takes the values 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 and not, as your selection suggests: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. In order to find the probability that X takes a certain value, you need to plug that value into the formula. So, for example, P(X = 1) = (1 + 2)(5 - 1) / 50 = 12/50. Please try again.

Good job! This is the right probability distribution. In order to find the probability that X takes a certain value, you need to plug that value into the formula. So, for example, P(X = 1) = (1 + 2)(5 - 1) / 50 = 12/50. Note that this is a legitimate probability distribution since all the probabilities are between 0 and 1, and their sum is 1.
